body: Fixed, looks like the the rename of the file got lost on the commit. I'm going to squash the commits then.

awesome thanks @jorgelbg . Great work. So this PR doesn't preclude having a JIRA and isn't mutually exclusive with it. Can you:
1. Create a JIRA for this PR?
2. Reference this PR in the JIRA? 

Then we can use the process described at http://github.com/apache/nutch/#contributing to commit it and I'd be happy to help. Cheers.
I created the JIRA [NUTCH-2095](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NUTCH-2095) I'll follow the procedure for committing.

Aye. All good AFAICS. I would suggest that in the future, if people are adding tests to this new class then it should be restructured to follow typical JUnit @SetUpClass @TearDownClass, etc.
+1 to merge.

@jorgelbg, am getting

```
./nutch org.apache.nutch.tools.CommonCrawlDataDumper -segment /data/nutch-dipe/crawl1k/segments/20150817184544/ -outputDir  /data/nutch-dipe/crawl1k/warc/20150817184544/ -warc
java.lang.RuntimeException: Missing output directory configuration: indexer.warc.output
```

Shouldn't that value be taken from the value of  -outputDir or are they meant to be different?

While we are at it, could you change the CCDD class so that it implements Tool?  It currently chokes on 
`/nutch org.apache.nutch.tools.CommonCrawlDataDumper -D indexer.warc.output=/data/nutch-dipe/crawl1k/warc/20150817184544/`
Always nicer to be able to pass config on the command line

@jorgelbg would also be good to pass either an individual segment or the whole directory containing the segments as we do for other tools. The name of the parameter is currently misleading (`-segment`) as in fact it considers the parent segments directory.

Also we should filter the content metadata that do not come from http response header i.e. the ones starting with _ or nutch.
Note that WARC-DATE should never be null as it is a mandatory value. If we can't generate a value at the correct format then the entry should be skipped altogether.

```
WARC/1.0
WARC-Type: response
WARC-Target-URI: http://11st.co.kr/
WARC-Date: null
WARC-IP-Address: 
WARC-Record-ID: <urn:uuid:9b4bd057-c361-4425-a5f8-cd4cd121665e>
Content-Type: application/http; msgtype=response
Content-Length: 967

Status: 
Hostname: 11st.co.kr
Address: 
Content-Encoding: 
Content-Type: text/html; charset=EUC-KR
Date: Mon, 17 Aug 2015 15:58:55 GMT
Server: Apache
_depth_: 1
Vary: User-Agent
Date: Mon, 17 Aug 2015 15:58:55 GMT
Content-Length: 369
_fst_: 33
nutch.segment.name: 20150817165846
Set-Cookie: JSESSIONID=GzspVSGfM2VPp4r8yNGM92RdJHmLRdm72Tjf1nFJWJJhLrTsn7xy!1924126666!-1408058590!9604!-1; path=/
_maxdepth_: 3
Content-Type: text/html; charset=EUC-KR
Connection: close
X-Powered-By: Servlet/2.4 JSP/2.0
Server: Apache
Cache-Control: no-cache="set-cookie"
```

One option is to return a resource instead of a response (i.e no http headers included) but I expect that it is still be better to have some noise in the headers than no http headers at all.

Are the http headers included in the Content-Length: ?

Could we also replace the spaces with %20 instead of skipping the entries that do not comply for WARC-Target-URI?

Last one, not clear what the warcSize value should be like? is it in bytes? Make that explicit in the option description

Thanks!

Also it would be good to be able to set a max size for the content and trim it accordingly. There is a special keyword in the WARC specs that allows you to declare that a content has been trimmed. Am getting memory exceptions when running the tool and I'm wondering whether it would make it more robust.

Plus it  would be good to detect whether the content had been trimmed while fetching and use that flag in such cases (see [https://github.com/DigitalPebble/nutch/blob/warcjn/src/java/org/apache/nutch/tools/warc/WARCExporter.java#L177]) for an example.

+1 good examples

Great work. Thanks @chrismattmann for bringing it to my attention. I will be on this as soon as possible.
Nice patch Kim.

We could also store the http headers as-is in the content metadata by adding a config like `http.store.httpheaders`; if we find a value under this key then we could use that for returning the response if not we could try and rebuild one by removing the key values added by Nutch as suggested above. This would guarantee a more accurate response entity in the WARC.

Nice

Also with the last commit the CCDD is able of reading a single segment or the "parent" directory with all the segments, should I add also the option of specifying several segments? I think this could be useful.

## 

_Lewis_

> The OOM exception is raised when writing to the WARC file?

yes + this is mentioned on the WIKI page for the CCDD

> Should we use the same *.content.limit configuration potion or use a CLI parameter instead?

I'd rather have a separate config option. no need to add it to the already long list of CLI parameters I think

> Also with the last commit the CCDD is able of reading a single segment or the "parent" directory with all the segments, should I add also the option of specifying several segments?

Why not but I'd rather have a consistent behaviour across our Tools and later on add that functionality to all of them - maybe make so that they use the same code for that

please close this then @prernasatija

Hi @jorgelbg. This is not ready to be committed yet as it generates incorrect HTTP headers.
You can use [https://bitbucket.org/nclarkekb/jwat-tools-gui/downloads] to verify the validity of the WARC files. [https://pypi.python.org/pypi/Warcat/] is also useful.

Am currently getting 

```
Status: 
Hostname: www.tescobank.com
Content-Encoding: gzip
Content-Type: text/html;charset=UTF-8
Date: Fri, 04 Sep 2015 14:26:58 GMT
Server: Tesco Bank
Server: Tesco Bank
Content-Encoding: gzip
Connection: close
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Set-Cookie: JSESSIONID=B9DDE1C6C396DD933E141842BA7426FF.node1; Path=/;HttpOnly
partialRefresh: true
Content-Type: text/html;charset=UTF-8
```

Note the double `Server` entry 

It should start with something like `HTTP/1.1 200 OK`. Could you clarify where that `Status` value comes from?

This reinforces my suggestion that we should capture the HTTP header in the low level HTTP response class instead of trying to regenerate it from the metadata. It would also preserve the real order in which headers were returned.
@jorgelbg see [https://github.com/DigitalPebble/nutch/commit/56bc80c35f152710e62a417ad60b37b501387b03] for storing request and response headers verbatim.

Missed that duplicated Server header. The status code is built from the `Metadata`, but with the option to store the raw request/response this becomes unnecessary (but configurable). You beat me to storing the raw request/response :) are you going to create a separated PR or should I incorporate those changes into this PR? Also we're going to keep this manual header processing as a backup option?

> Are you going to create a separated PR or should I incorporate those changes into this PR?

Please add to this PR (have just pushed a fix for a stupid bug in there)

> Also we're going to keep this manual header processing as a backup option?

No, let's return an WARC element of type 'resource' if no headers have been found, much cleaner I think and still very useful.

Also we shouldn't generate the Date from the one taken from the Http headers [https://github.com/DigitalPebble/nutch/blob/warc/src/java/org/apache/nutch/tools/CommonCrawlFormatWARC.java#L167] but maybe add a clean new metadata at the right format within the Fetcher e.g. `nutch.fetch.date`, unless we already have something like this somewhere.

I have no problem in defining this metadata for the fetch time, I was kind of guiding by the explanation of the Date header in the HTTP RFC. But truth be told, is not very good to rely on this as you said.
Also in the case that no `_request_` key is found in the Metadata object we should skip and generate only the response record right?

> Also in the case that no _request_ key is found in the Metadata object we should skip and generate only the response record right?

yes
@chrismattmann, closing this one creating a new PR with JIRA issue. And before committing the webui I have to get https://github.com/apache/nutch/pull/59 committed.

@chrismattmann, I have tried to keep this backwards compatible so that nutch-python can work without any changes. In case if you have any test cases written already, please do share, I'll test it with those too :)

Perhaps `CrawlDatum.fetchTime` could be used, but since this can have the date of the future crawl date of an URL see received https://github.com/apache/nutch/blob/trunk/src/java/org/apache/nutch/crawl/CrawlDatum.java#L178-L184 But the index-basic plugin rely on this property for indexing the fetched time, so any comments on this?
I assume the value found in crawl_fetch would be correct, let's use that

Ok chaps, I've just opened [https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NUTCH-2102] which has a patch creating a WARCExporter based on MapReduce whereas the CCDD is a local file, single JVM sort of thing. As explained there, we will have a WARCImporter later on, which is outside the scope of the CCDD anyway + strictly speaking WARC is not specific to CommonCrawl so the package name I used in NUTCH-2102 is probably more appropriate.

That patch contains the changes to HttpResponse.java that we have here, whichever approach gets committed first - if any - means that we'd need to modify the other but no big deal.

Personally I'd have no problem in having some duplication of functionality between NUTCH-2012 and this improvement to the CCDD (we've done a lot worse over the years). Maybe if and when the CCDD is based on MapReduce and supports IO on DFS then we can reconsider whether to keep NUTCH-2102 or not.

Great work @jorgelbg to integrate this into the existing export framework for CCDD - and now you have a new NUTCH-2102 that is based off M/R. I am fine as long as NUTCH-2102 is a basis for turning all the jobs into M/R. I'll take a look at it. Thanks @jnioche
cc / @giuseppetotaro

> the nutch.fetch.time is initialized with the CrawlDatum.fetchTime property, on the HttpResponse class since now the CCDD only reads the content of the segment and doesn't read any other data. Any suggestion on this?

Just  modify the protocol so that it creates 'nutch.fetch.time' in the content medatata. Taking the Dates returned by the servers does not give any guarantee that they are accurate, let alone that they exist.
are we good to commit this? @lewismc
I've just squashed the changes into a single commit.

Actually I think that @jnioche has a point, in terms of scalability NUTCH-2102 has a better approach. The ideal approach could be to merge both tools into one. That will run locally and at scale (which is one of the main points of Nutch).
OK great work @sujen1412 I am +1 to commit this. @lewismc I will go ahead and commit this shortly.
OK #59 is committed now. So I'll close this one out. Then please open a new one with the integration :) :+1:

@chrismattmann we are good to commit this, since the branch name is not in the format defined in https://github.com/apache/nutch/#contributing there is any additional step required? Or can I commit like usual?
@jnioche happy with incremental steps. @jorgelbg feel free to commit as usual or attach the patch however you feel fit. Great work as usual!
One quick comment - my group extensively uses CCDD - even on medium crawls. We just dump on a big head node. Does this alter that behavior?

Yes, this doesn't change the default behavior of CCDD, this only adds the option of also exporting into the WARC format. So change to the implemented logic was done.

Hey @asitang,

I was thinking about this last night. I think we may have missed a few points when we were talking about this previously. All the Driver creation, clean up, and content pulling are done in lib-selenium so we can use that functionality across plugins. I think we can add this functionality without many (or any) changes though.

If you want to to do multiple content extractions and include that with the body, the handler can do that by incrementally pulling content out of the page and appending (or replacing) the body of the fetched page. This effectively allows the handler to return whatever subset of data that it wants and it doesn't require us to make any changes. I think that's probably a reasonably clean way of handling the functionality.

Thoughts?
Do you mean we can keep appending the new content to the driver instance and return it??

OK will scope and provide feedback ASAP.
Thanks for this what an effort!
Please close this off @kwhitehall thank you

Hey @asitang,

If I'm remembering correctly we were talking about wanting to pull content out of various parts of the page and append that to the body in the same interaction correct? So in psudocode:

```
public void processDriver(WebDriver driver) {
  String stuffWeCareAbout = ""
  for allInteractionsWeNeedToDo {
    driver.doInteraction()
    stuffWeCareAbout += fetchHTMLFromTheInteractionWeDid()
  }
  driver.appendToBody(stuffWeCareAbout)
}
```

Wouldn't this cover the use case we were looking to handle sufficiently? Or in other words, if we want to do a bunch of interactions that generate content on a page the workflow per-interaction is:
- Do the interaction on the driver
- Grab the content this generates that we care about and save it into a variable
- Undo the interaction if necessary

Once all the interactions we care about are done, we append this content to the body (or completely replace the body even).

## 

So imagine an example of a paginated table that dynamically loads content. This should handle what we're looking for I think (again, pseudocode)

```
public void processDriver(WebDriver driver) {
  String paginatedTableContent = ""
  for tableInteractions {
    if (! onFirstTablePage)
      driver.clickPaginationButton()

    paginatedTableContent += driver.table.innerHTML
  }
  driver.appendToBody(stuffWeCareAbout)
}
```

Now when we process all the links coming out of this page they'll all be coming off the page with the table.
Thank you @zhangmianhongni for this patch. Good catch.
Yup I got that part Mike. But I don't think this is possible in selenium: driver.appendToBody(stuffWeCareAbout)
great work. Note in general when committing if you say in your commit message "this closes #<GITHUB ISSUE NUMBER>" the asfbot will close it for you on SVN commit hook. Thanks @jorgelbg @jnioche

Hi @sujen1412 
I wonder if you could name your issues as you would add them in the CHANGES.txt?
e.g. 

```
NUTCH-2135 Ant Eclipse build does not include protocol-interactiveselenium
```

This way it is much easier for people to see what the issue relates to and whether or not they are interested in either reviewing it, or pulling it locally and testing it.
This is just a suggestion, it is by no means a requirement. Great work.

LGTM, minor updates to:
- remove author tags
- why does lucene have to be added to the main Ivy?
- it looks like you did more than simply use Lucene for term vectorizing and for tokenizing. Are you using Lucene to actually store and retrieve the feature vector for similarity?

Thanks @chrismattmann for the feedback. 

> why does lucene have to be added to the main Ivy?

> it looks like you did more than simply use Lucene for term vectorizing and for tokenizing. Are you using Lucene to actually store and retrieve the feature vector for similarity?

I am currently only term vectorizing and tokenizing using Lucene, the storing and retrieval functionality can be used in the future versions of this plugin. I did remove the file from commit, but I guess squashing all created some error. Will update this with the removal of author tags. 

Thanks.
